Little Red Rosa
 
 AS A VETERAN ACTIVIST, Rosa Parks earned a major role in a Communist production entitled "The Civil Rights Movement." She played her part convincingly for fifty years, from 1955 to her death last month: that of the courageous little seamstress who refused to relinquish her bus seat to a White man.
 
 At the time of Parks' arrest, standing by with bail money was her attorney, Clifford Durr, who entered a plea of 'not guilty' on her behalf. Photo-ops had been arranged. Durr was a close associate of Jessica Mitford, an official of the Communist Party. In 1949, he joined the communnist front National Lawyers Guild.
 
 Prior to Rosa Parks' planned arrest for violating the segregation law, the Alabama NAACP leadership arranged for her to attend the Highlander Folk School in Monteagle, Tennessee. Parks attended summer training there in 1955, 1956, and 1957. In a letter to FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover, a field agent wrote: "This school is a hotbed of communism and anarchy."
 
 Another FBI memorandum to J. Edgar Hoover described the school, which was founded in 1932, as a "Communist front" whose purpose was to "better control their unions and to give instruction on how to cause and carry on their strikes." A third memo described the school as "spreading Communist propaganda and training agitators and propagandists."

Although she really doesn't deserve the recognition she's gotten. She wasn't the only one to think it was wrong and protest. Jackie Robinson did the same thing in the military BEFORE she did.  But again, Jackie Robinson did it (I think 3 years) earlier than Rosa Parks. And she didn't really do much. I also recently heard something about how she sat in the front for 5 days before she could get someone to tell her to go to the back. She was just the puppet leader. She didn't do a single thing to help advance the civil rights movement other than do what her friend at the NAACP told her to. Sure, during the civil rights movement she could have been a hero with all the media coverage. But now that we're looking back, we can see that she really didn't do anything heroic that was not done before by others. Sure she didn't say no when the NAACP guy asked her to sit in the front, but maybe that was because she was "timid" as well. She didn't fight for rights, she was just the puppet leader. Yet here we are, 50 years later, still celebrating her. Do we mark the aniversary of Jackie Robinson sitting in the front of the bus? I'd even venture to say that Rosa Parks sitting in the front of the bus was more publicized than the 50th aniversary of Jackie Robinson playing in the major leagues, which was a whole lot more than just sitting down and being arrested one day.
